abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the project is
            unsatisfactory, since the key objective, institutional
            strengthening was not met. Nevertheless, engineering designs
            and dam construction related studies, such as the
            environmental assessment and resettlement action plan, were
            successfully accomplished and completed. Initially, the Bank
            responded properly to identification, appraisal, and
            negotiations prior to board presentation, but failed to
            provide adequate attention to broad institutional building
            issues, as well as corrective actions regarding the
            Government's default on the Credit Agreement clauses
            with respect to the Performance Contract. The Government
            took actions in contradiction to the project's
            objectives, thus disrupting implementation; furthermore, the
            default on the performance contract delayed the required
            tariff increases, failing to provide adequate financial
            statements. Considering both the Bank and the
            borrower's performances as unsatisfactory, it is
            suggested that: 1) an engineering credit could be
            appropriate for financing studies in future complex
            operations; 2) integrated environmental assessments could be
            completed well ahead of project implementation, financed
            through an engineering credit, to effectively address large
            infrastructure requirements; 3) based on past experience,
            the Bank should have engaged the Borrower in sector
            restructuring, leading to private sector participation.
